awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Getting the Most out of Secure Multi-Party Computation
awd_abstract_narration:
Our society is becoming increasingly reliant on powerful and interconnected computing devices that store much of our personal information. These devices present an ever-growing tension between the desire for our personal information to be private, and the desire to put our personal information to good use for our own convenience. In cryptography, problems that involve requirements of useful computation and privacy are understood through the lens of secure multi-party computation (SMPC). Specifically, SMPC refers to the problem of how mutually distrusting parties can securely and collaboratively perform tasks that involve private information.

In this project, the PI will develop new techniques for understanding and overcoming the challenges and limitations posed by SMPC protocols. In particular, the following major themes will be explored: (1) is it possible in the real world to design protocols that remain secure regardless of other concurrently running protocols? (2) what security properties can be embedded into objects like ciphertexts and digital signatures? (3) how can shared data be maintained persistently while remaining private? The PI will develop new materials for undergraduate courses in cryptography and algorithms, based on principles of pedagogically sound visualization. The PI will also create resources for the cryptography research community, in the form of an online database of cryptographic constructions and primitives.

por.por_cntn:
Secure multi-party computation (MPC) allows 2 or more parties to perform a computation on private data and learn only the outcome of that computation (i.e., they learn nothing about the private inputs, other than what can be inferred from the output). This project has made the following fundmental contributions to MPC:

1. In principle, any computation can be carried out under secure computation. One of the leading techniques for converting an arbitrary computation to a secure one is known as garbled circuits. An outcome of this project has been to essentially settle the question of concrete efficiency for garbled boolean circuits, with a sequence of new techniques and a proof of their optimality. We also introduced the first practical techniques for garbling arithmetic circuits.

2. Private set intersection (PSI) is a special case of MPC, where the parties each hold a set of items and wish to learn which items are common to all sets. PSI has many real-world applications, and is known to be actively used in industry. This project has resulted in the fastest PSI protocols for 2-party PSI (for security against either passive or active adversaries) and multi-party PSI.

3. A challenge in MPC is to guarantee security even against attackers that may deviate arbitrarily from the protocol. An outcome of this project has been new protocol techniques to strengthen protocols against such attacks. These new techniques are faster, have better scalability for larger computations, and in some cases provide compelling tradeoffs between security and performance.

4. Traditional approaches for general-purpose MPC work by first converting the desired computation to a boolean or arithmetic circuit and then performing a protocol to securely evaluate that circuit. Many real-world computations do not lend themselves to small circuits. An outcome of this project has been new MPC techniques based on a different model of computation known as the random-access machine (RAM) model. In many cases, computations in the RAM model are exponentially more efficient than the equivalent circuit-model computation. Hence, these new protocol techniques demonstrate better scalability for secure computations on large data.

In addition to these outcomes, the project has also supported the PI's development of a free online undergraduate textbook in cryptography, and a suite of web-based visualization tools for intermediate/advanced algorithm topics.
